webTitle: Amtrak ordered to improve safety and increase speed  limit signage

fields.standfirst: According to investigators, train was traveling at about 106mph as it approached a left-hand turn where it then derailed on Tuesday
fields.body:
Related: Families of eight Amtrak crash victims mourn loved ones

Amtrak has been ordered to improve safety and increase signage informing of maximum speeds on its Northeast Corridor route, the Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) said on Saturday.

On Tuesday night, an Amtrak train traveling from Washington DC to New York derailed moments after leaving Philadelphia. Five crew members and 238 passengers were on board. Eight people were killed.

On Friday, National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) investigators asked the FBI to examine a remnant of the Amtrak locomotive’s shattered windshield, in order to determine if the train had been struck by an object prior to its derailment.

In a statement on Saturday, Amtrak said its “overarching goal is to provide safe and secure rail passenger travel. We will immediately implement the Federal Railroad Administration’s directives to further improve passenger train safety along the Northeast Corridor”.

Regional Train 188 was traveling at about 106mph as it approached a left-hand turn where it derailed, according to NTSB investigators. According to the NTSB’s Robert Sumwalt, the speed limit before the curve was 80mph, dropping to 50mph at the curve. In the three seconds after the emergency break was activated by the train’s engineer, the train slowed to about 102mph.

“We are pretty confident that the train was traveling within one to two miles of those speeds,” Sumwalt said on Wednesday.

According to Sumwalt, the track where the accident occurred was not fitted with the Advanced Civil Speed Enforcement System (ACSES). ACSES is part of the Positive Train Control (PTC) system, which automatically enforces speed limits by slowing down or stopping trains that are going too fast or heading into danger zones.

“It’s on our most-wanted list,” Sumwalt said of the ACSES system. “Congress has mandated that it be installed by the end of this year … based on what we know right now, we feel that had such a system been installed in this section of track, this accident would not have occurred.”

On Saturday, the FRA ordered Amtrak to ensure that an automatic speed control system was put into use on northbound trains on the corridor, which stretches from Washington to Boston. The regulators also ordered the railroad to assess the risk on curves in the track and to increase signage regarding maximum speeds.

In its statement, Amtrak said it was “also reviewing whether it can partially activate some of the capabilities of the Advanced Civil Speed Enforcement System … components already installed in the Northeast Corridor. Amtrak will evaluate whether such an option can be undertaken without delaying the complete activation of PTC in the Northeast Corridor later this year.”

Related: Amtrak's Northeast Corridor: train crash occurred on America's busiest network

The northeastern regional service is Amtrak’s busiest, running about 22 hourly departures daily; more than 2,200 trains operate on the Washington-Boston route each day. In 2014, about 11.6 million passengers traveled the corridor, up 3.3% from 2013.

“Although our current focus is on the passengers and employees affected by this incident and the resulting service disruption along the Northeast Corridor, we must also take time to learn from this event,” Joe Boardman, president and chief executive of Amtrak, wrote in an email to Amtrak customers on Saturday.

“Passenger railroading is at its core about people; the safety of our passengers and employees was, is and always will be our number one priority.

Our goal is to fully understand what happened and how we can prevent a similar tragedy from occurring in the future.”

webTitle: Co-op Group averts legal action by agreeing to change composition of board

fields.standfirst: Bosses confirm political ties with Co-operative party will remain, as they faced turbulent AGM in which members grilled them over high wages
fields.body:
The Co-operative party, aligned to Labour, is to continue to receive up to £1m a year from the Co-operative Group after a tight vote at the annual general meeting of the UK’s biggest mutual.

The chairman, Allan Leighton, was forced to admit that the subscription to the party would continue at the end of the four-hour AGM, where he faced hostile questioning about pay polices and boardroom reform.

He made repeated passionate attempts to win round the 1,000 or so members assembled in Manchester at the first AGM to be run under a one-member-one-vote system, which replaced the block vote method of the past.

A vote brought by members on political donations was passed with 55% in favour, while a complex three-part motion tabled by the board on whether to keep political donations failed.

There was a protest vote against pay and boardroom elections. More than one in three of the votes cast at the AGM rejected the pay report. If deliberate abstentions are included, 33% failed to back the pay policies, while 22% voted against. Leighton – chairman since February – also faced a protest vote; 30% failed to back his election, while 17% voted against. Other board members, including the chief executive Richard Pennycook, also faced dissent.

The pay protest came after £3m pay deal for for the former HR director Rebecca Skitt, who worked for the group for 11 months, was raised by members, as was the £2.5m paid to Pennycook. One member described the sums as exorbitant while another asked Pennycook if he would work for £1m.

Related: New Co-operative chairman braces himself for the annual meeting

The turnaround expert was not allowed to answer by Leighton who insisted the boss was worth every penny. Asked by reporters after the meeting if he would do the job for less, Pennycook refused to answer.

Members also raised the £6.6m pay deal that been offered to Euan Sutherland, who walked out last year when details of his pay were leaked to the Observer, and as the group was battling to bailout the banking arm. Leighton said: “Under my watch it ain’t going to happen again. Some of the numbers are very high”.

Pennycook is trying to turnaround the Co-op which lost £2.5bn in 2013 after the problems in the bank and an overexpansion of its supermarket arm. Frank Nelson, who sits on the board and chairs the remuneration committee, added that the team of “Red Adair don’t come cheap”.

There were cheers as one member asked why the organisation paid out such large executive salaries when it did not pay the living wage. Nelson said the £7.28 hourly wage was 93% of the living wage.

Leighton, a former chairman of Royal Mail and the first independent chairman, attempted to convince the members of his credentials, showing black-and-white family photos of him from the 1960s with his father, who used to work for the Co-op. He said he had a “very big emotional attachment”.

As members attended the meeting, they were greeted by Co-op party activists in purple T-shirts handing them red apples – a reference to remarks by Leighton in the Guardian last month when he said: “It’s the apples, not the activists, that will turn the Co-op around.”

Stella Creasy, the Labour and Co-op MP, tweeted from the hall: “Co-op Group claim cooperatives all about apples not activists” in reference to the apples. Karin Christiansen, Co-op party general secretary, said she was excited about the outcome of the vote. “The Co-operative Party has been the political voice of the co-operative movement for 98 years and we look forward to continuing our successful relationship with the Co-operative Group in light of today’s clear and decisive result,” she said.

“The Co-operative party looks forward to working with the Co-operative Group’s board and new national members’ council to plan our future work together,” she said. The Co-op has 24 MPs in parliament, down 31 before the election when senior figures such as Ed Balls lost their seat. One member from Scotland questioned whether the link with Labour had damaged the Co-op.

Leighton, best known for turning around Asda, said to reporters after the vote on political donations: “There’s clarity – a remit from the members to continue to support the Co-op Labour party.” The vote is only advisory to the board which agreed last year to give £625,000 to the Co-op party for 18 months.

Related: Future of £1m Co-operative party subscriptions hangs in balance

Before the meeting began, the Co-op Group rushed out a statementthat averted legal action from one of its biggest owners by promising to increase the representation of members on its board and agreeing to change the process for selecting candidates.

Members are to be another seat on its board – taking the number to four – and ensure that more than one candidate for each would be put forward for election in the future. The Midcounties – the largest of the independent co-ops that together own 22% of the group – had threatened an injunction over the process over which three member-nominated directors were being election to the board.

The Midcounties had taken legal advice after the board reduced a shortlist of six candidates for three member-nominated directors to three – avoiding the contested elections that long-standing co-op activists had expected.

In a joint statement, the board and the members council, chaired by Lesley Reznicek, pledged to conduct the process differently next year by making applications more straightforward and creating an academy to train potential candidates for the board.

Future elections to the board for member-nominated directors would be contested, he said. When the results were flashed up on the board, Hazel Blears, the former Labour minister, was elected despite a 36% vote against.

Up to 7 million members own the Co-op, along with the independent societies, and around 2.5m were eligible to vote at the AGM. Just over 90,000 voted before the AGM.
